text:
*[Bug 18656] New: Allow interrupting pmatch()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18656>

            Bug ID: 18656
           Summary: Allow interrupting pmatch()
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.3.x
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Low-level
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:ikrylov@disroot.org|ikrylov@disroot.org>

Created attachment 3289
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3289&action=edit>
Check for interrupts during the second pass

Originally discussed on
[R-devel](<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2023-December/083066.html>).
Given a large data frame (1M rows) and a large, poorly matching set of rows to
extract, `[.data.frame` -> `pmatch()` will take a quadratic amount of
`strncmp()` calls to complete, which takes a long time. There are no
destructors to run manually inside `do_pmatch`, so there is little additional
complexity in an extra call to `R_CheckUserInterrupt()`.

Thanks to Simon Urbanek for letting me know about a faster idiom (`counter &
bitmask`) than I had originally suggested (`if (--counter < threshold) { reset
counter... }`).

*[Bug 18655] Enhancements to `*wilcox` functions for large population sizes*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18655>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #6 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Just some thoughts/remark from one R-core member:

1. Thanks a lot to Andreas Loeffler; the link to its first post (Jan 15) is
   <https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2024-January/083124.html>

2. shaving a few percent of speed is *not* important. Rather is well
maintainable, i.e., nicely human readable and verifyable (e.g., close to the
published algorithm notation!) source code,
and of course getting rid of extraneous large memory consumption and other
scaling issues of usual ways of recursive algorithms.

Also, of course going from O((mn)^2)  to O(mn)  memory consumption *is*
crucial.
So, thank you very much, Andreas and Aidan.

text:
*[Bug 18655] Enhancements to `*wilcox` functions for large population sizes*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18655>

--- Comment #8 from Aidan H Lakshman (<mailto:AHL27@pitt.edu|AHL27@pitt.edu>) ---
(In reply to Martin Maechler from comment #6)

Thanks for your comments and feedback, Martin (and for linking the r-devel
discussion)! 

Agreed. My view is that this implementation is simpler and thus more
maintainable, but that may be personal bias. As for human
readability/verifiability, I believe the current version is good, but I'll go
through it today to add more comments/description as necessary.

My concern on speed is primarily the `qwilcox(q, 50, 50)` case, in which the
old version runs 1,000x faster than the new version (9 microseconds vs. 1
millisecond). Lower population sizes do have differences in speed, but those
are on the order of microseconds, so they're probably not noticeable to users.
I'll also note that repeated calls to `qwilcox` do decrease the performance
gap--`qwilcox(seq(0,1,0.01), 50, 50)` is only about 2x slower in the new
version (750 microseconds vs. 1.788 milliseconds). 

And again, once either population is larger than 50, the current version
performs much slower. Even `qwilcox(0.5, 10, 51)` runs 10x faster in the new
version.

So, my main question is, is this performance tradeoff worth it for the changes
proposed? This change would provide a noticeably **large increase** in
performance for large population sizes, an arguably **non-noticeable decrease**
in performance for small population sizes, and a **noticeable decrease** in
performance for single calls when both populations are close to (but less than)
50. 

I personally think that's a good tradeoff, since the case where the new version
is much slower is narrow enough to be uncommon, and because I doubt users will
be making repeated separate calls to `qwilcox`.

elements.text:
) ---

`wilcox.c` with the exception of some additional comments.

*[Bug 18656] Allow interrupting pmatch()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18656>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #1 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Thank you, Ivan.

Note that  `unique.c` has about a dozen *commented* (i.e. disabled)
`R_CheckUserInterrupt()` calls in other functions.
We had commented them because they did cause a notable penalty.

Still, your check (including the choice of  0x1fff = 8191) seems to have been
careful such that I don't easily see any measurable CPU usage increase.
and I can quite quickly interrupt as the check is in the inner loop.

and I can quite quickly interrupt as the check is in the inner loop.

text:
*[Bug 18654] xyTable fails when both x and y are NA*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18654>

Heather Turner (<mailto:ht@heatherturner.net|ht@heatherturner.net>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Attachment #3284|0                           |1
        is obsolete|                            |
   Attachment #3285|0                           |1
        is obsolete|                            |

--- Comment #4 from Heather Turner (<mailto:ht@heatherturner.net|ht@heatherturner.net>) ---
Created attachment 3291
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3291&action=edit>
Updated patch

Going in to the detail of the code:

* `order(x, y)` orders NAs last, but how it orders the NAs is unimportant here
* `first` is is intended to identify when either the ordered x co-ordinates or
the ordered y co-ordinates change to a new value. The bug in the current code
comes from the fact that `z != NA` is `NA`, regardless of the value of `z`. So
the code 
    ```(x[-1L] != x[-n]) | (y[-1L] != y[-n])```
returns `NA`  when both comparisons involve an NA value.

Writing this I realise you'll also get `NA` when one comparison is `FALSE` and
the other is `NA`. So it's possible to create another case that breaks both the
current code and my previous patch:

```
## Case 5: NA in y when x is duplicated
iris5 <- iris[1:10, 3:4]
iris5[4, 2] <- NA
xyTable(iris5)
#> $x
#> [1] 1.3 1.4 1.4 1.5 1.5  NA 1.7
#> 
#> $y
#> [1] 0.2 0.2 0.3 0.1 0.2  NA 0.4
#> 
#> $number
#> [1]  1  4  1  1 NA NA  1
```

So I think the simplest and most robust solution is to use 

```first <- !duplicated(cbind(x, y))```

which directly computes what we're after, even though it may be a little less
efficient for data without NAs. I attach an updated patch.

Note that this code was originally part of `sunflowerplot()` which will drop
any co-ordinates with NAs, but since the code has been extracted into its own
function I think it's reasonable to count them, so that
`sum(xyTable(dat)$number)` will be equal to `nrow(dat)`.

Some plotting methods make use of missing values, see e.g.
<https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/naniar/readme/README.html>. Since they
are easy to remove before/after as required, I think it is better if xyTable
can handle them.

        is obsolete|                            |
